tossups.question: A set of "genetically encoded indicators" of this element are used with a fluorescence microscope to image neurons. Antibodies against transporters of this element cause a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small cell lung cancer, called Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. An increase in levels of this element leads to exocytosis of cortical granules during the slow block to polyspermy. (*) Desmoglein is part of a family of cell adhesion molecules regulated by binding to this element. Transmission of impulses down T-tubules activates the release of this element from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of myocytes. Low levels of phosphate and this element can cause rickets. For 10 points, name this element whose intestinal absorption is increased by vitamin D.
tossups.answer: Calcium or Ca2+

tossups.question: This body of water surrounds a ghost town that was formerly its country's largest fishing village, Saint Martin of the Tigers, found on Tigres Island. This body of water produces a dense fog called cassimbo along part of its coastline. While walking beaches along this body of water, tourists can observe the rusted MV Dunedin Star cargo ship. A thin desert along the coast of this body of water, the Kakoveld, is where it receives the flow of the ephemeral (*) Swakop river. Surfers frequent a shipwreck-laden strand along this body of water called the Skeleton Coast, which is the product of irregularities in the Benguela ("behn-GWAY-luh") Current arising in its southern gyre. The exclave of Cabinda and the capital city of Luanda both touch, for 10 points, what ocean that forms the coasts of Namibia and Angola?
tossups.answer: Atlantic Ocean [accept South Atlantic; prompt on Walvis Bay by asking "what larger body is Walvis Bay part of?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Atlantic Ocean [accept South Atlantic; prompt on Walvis Bay by asking "what larger body is Walvis Bay part of?]
promptable: Walvis Bay by asking "what larger body is Walvis Bay part of?

tossups.question: A piece in this musical genre includes variations of the song "Wenn ich ein Vöglein wär" ("venn eesh yne VOE-ghlyne VEHR") in its Andante third movement, titled "from a train in Germany". Movements titled Pulse I and Pulse II appear in a piece in this genre by Esa-Pekka Salonen. André Previn's piece in this genre is dedicated to Anne-Sophie Mutter. A G minor piece in this genre unusually begins with a prelude, or Vorspiel ("VOR-shpeel"), which leads directly into its E-flat major Adagio. Sarah (*) Chang won admission to Juilliard by performing that piece in this genre, written by Max Bruch ("mahks brookh"). Many pieces in this genre of orchestral music are written in D major, including those by Brahms, Beethoven, and Tchaikovsky. For 10 points, name this genre of classical music written for orchestra and a high-pitched string soloist.
tossups.answer: violin concerto [prompt on concerto]

tossups.question: A story by this author is titled for a cursed object in which a man found 1000 gold coins to pay his rent, which mysteriously disappears from the wall at the story’s end during an auction. In another story by this author, a painter takes opium and slices his throat after learning that the dark-haired beauty he followed was a prostitute. Yet another story by this author of "The Portrait" ends as a watchman sees a phantom with an (*) "enormous mustache" disappear across a bridge. In one of his stories, Pirogorov ("pee-REE-goh-roff") and Piskarev ("pee-SKAR-yoff") part on the title street, while in another, a copyist uses his Christmas bonus to buy the services of the tailor Petrovich to repair the title garment. For 10 points, name this Russian author whose Petersburg Tales include "Nevsky Prospekt" and "The Overcoat".
tossups.answer: Nikolai Gogol

tossups.question: 3,500 workers in this profession went on an impromptu strike to support Alice Moore's campaign against her county's textbooks. An armored train known as the "Bull Moose Special" fired on workers in this profession during a conflict against governor William E. Glasscock. Teddy Roosevelt negotiated a 10% wage increase for workers in this profession following a 1902 strike. Workers in this profession opposed John D. (*) Rockefeller Jr. in a deadly strike known as the Ludlow Massacre. James McParland infiltrated a secret society made up of workers in this profession known as the Molly Maguires. Workers in this profession fought the Battle of Blair Mountain against detectives and bosses in West Virginia. Black lung afflicted many workers with, for 10 points, what fossil-fuel-extracting job?
tossups.answer: coal miners [prompt on miners]

tossups.question: A play from this country adapts a story about a divorcee who marries a carpenter and empties a bucket in front of her ex-husband, one source of the proverb "Poured water cannot be retrieved". In another play from this country, an accused woman prophesies that three unnatural events, including the fall of snow in midsummer, will prove that injustice was done to her. Actresses in plays from this country manipulate long garments attached to their gowns in the (*) "water sleeves" technique. Some plays from this country adapt the stories of the White Snake and the 36 "earthly fiends" and 72 "heavenly spirits" among the Stars of Destiny; those are examples of its dramatic operas, one variety of which is named for its capital. For 10 points, what Asian country's classic novels include Water Margin?
tossups.answer: China [or Zhōngguó] (The first play is Lanke Mountain and the second is Injustice to Dou E.)
tossups.metadata: The first play is Lanke Mountain and the second is Injustice to Dou E.

tossups.question: A history of this empire likens one of its enemies and his son to a caterpillar and a locust, respectively, and begins by commenting on "the stream of time, irresistible, ever moving". Writing about another ruler of this empire, a historian recalls the implementation of a villainous "sky-tax" and an instance in which the emperor strolled through his palace without a head. That same historian claimed that a (*) plague which struck this empire killed "10,000 times 10,000 times 10,000" people, and that one of its empresses climbed the social ladder through her career as a tavern dancer. Robert Guiscard's ("roh-BARE ghees-CAR'Z") Norman invasion of this empire is described in a history written by its princess Anna Comnena. For 10 points, Procopius recorded the history of what empire during the reign of Justinian I?
tossups.answer: Byzantine Empire [or Eastern Roman Empire; or Basileia Rhomaion]

tossups.question: Poetry accompanied pictures by this artist in an April 2020 online MoMA ("moh-mah") exhibition titled for this artist's "Words and Pictures". This artist took pictures of the hands and feet of Indonesian dancers while accompanying Paul Taylor on a trip to Asia. A photograph by this artist of young men on a porch was transformed into a propaganda poster reading "This is your America... Keep it free!" This artist took pictures of (*) empty roads for the collection An American Exodus. Photographs of a man hoisting his grandson on his back and of an American flag flying in front of a barracks were taken by this artist for the War Relocation Board. Another of her photographs shows two children leaning on the shoulders of Florence Owens Thompson. For 10 points, name this photographer of Migrant Mother.
tossups.answer: Dorothea Lange

tossups.question: Following the establishment of Jerusalem's first Yemenite communities, Sephardim discriminated against them specifically for using a different type of these objects. Particularly valued examples of these objects, often prepared in the afternoon before use, are called shmurah. Deuteronomy describes these objects as a "reminder of affliction" in a commandment requiring their use. Fruit juice replaces water in the preparation of the inaccurately-named (*) egg form of these objects. On one occasion, children are encouraged to search for one of these objects called the afikoman, which is the last one to be used during the night's meal. A food made of maror and two of these objects is named for Rabbi Hillel. For 10 points, because Jews fleeing Egypt couldn't wait for their bread to rise, what unleavened bread is eaten on Passover?
tossups.answer: pieces of matzo [or matzah; before "bread", prompt on unleavened bread or flatbread]
tossups.answer_formatted: pieces of matzo [or matzah; before "bread", prompt on unleavened bread or flatbread]

tossups.question: Spaces that, like these objects, have the 0th and nth homology groups isomorphic to the integers and all others trivial, are the "homology" type of these objects. The homotopy groups of a space consist of equivalence classes of basepoint-preserving maps from these objects to the space. Milnor found spaces that are homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic to these objects in dimension 7, called their "exotic" variety. Any simply connected closed (*) 3-manifold is homeomorphic to these objects of dimension 3 by the Poincaré conjecture. Parameters l and m define a basis for harmonic functions on these objects, which arise by separating angular and radial parts in their namesake coordinates. For 10 points, what objects consist of all points in Euclidean space that are the same distance from a center?
tossups.answer: n-spheres [on n-dimensional spheres; or spheres of dimension n; or hyperspheres; accept homology spheres, exotic (7-)spheres, spherical harmonics, or spherical coordinates; accept answers using another variable or stating any specific positive integer in place of n; accept circles; prompt on Sn (same note as for the other n); do not accept or prompt on "balls" or "disks"; do not accept or prompt on answers using any other common-language synonym for "sphere" or "circle"]
tossups.answer_formatted: n-spheres [on n-dimensional spheres; or spheres of dimension n; or hyperspheres; accept homology spheres, exotic]

tossups.question: The shipping firm Seamaster sponsors several tournaments in this sport, such as T2 Diamond. A Swedish player of this sport was given the nickname "Evergreen Tree" by Chinese fans for his cross-decade consistency. Prior to a match of this sport in Nagoya, Glenn Cowan handed his opponent a shirt with a peace sign and The Beatles' lyric "Let it Be". Players of this sport, especially (*) Tomokazu Harimoto, often shout "Cho-le!" after winning a competitive point. A 1972 invitation for an American team in this sport to visit China led to the coining of a term for "diplomacy" named for this sport. Players in this sport strike with loops to add backspin to the ball and often use aggressive "smashes" to try to score. Two players hit a ball across a net using paddles in, for 10 points, what sport?
tossups.answer: table tennis [or ping pong; do not prompt or accept "tennis"] (The first clue refers to Jan-Ove Waldner.)
tossups.answer_formatted: table tennis [or ping pong; do not prompt or accept "tennis"]
tossups.metadata: The first clue refers to Jan-Ove Waldner.

tossups.question: This practice is examined within the context of the "general economy," in which it turns dépense ("day-POHNS") into a method of "humiliating" others, in George Bataille's book The Accursed Share. Part of this practice in which a boy receives a "third name" is discussed in a paper which examines links between this practice and secret societies called Hamatsa. The Salish wear moon masks during ceremonial dances which are part of this practice, which is identified as an extreme, agonistic form of a "total (*) social institution" in a 1925 essay comparing it to the Melanesian kula economy. In protest of Canada's ban on this practice, Franz Boas hosted an example with friends from the Kwakwaka'wakw ("kwah-kwuh-kyuh-wakw") people he studied. Marcel Mauss's The Gift discusses, for 10 points, what feasts of Northwest Pacific peoples?
tossups.answer: potlach [or potlaches; prompt on gift giving; prompt on potluck]

tossups.question: James Augustus Hicky founded a "gazette" named after this region, becoming its country's first newspaper. A ruler of this region encouraged William Jones to found a scholarly society in it. John Zephaniah Holwell's "genuine narrative of" some "deplorable deaths" is key to our knowledge of an event that took place in this region. Mir Qasim ("meer-kuh-SEEM"), who betrayed a ruler of this region along with his father-in-law Mir (*) Jafar, would himself be deposed following the Battle of Buxar. The forced cultivation of opium over food crops was one cause of a "great" 1770 famine that affected this region. Siraj ud-Daulah ("see-RAJ ood-DOW-luh"), the last nawab ("nuh-WAHB") of this region, was defeated by Robert Clive at the Battle of Plassey. For 10 points, name this region which would later become an Indian state whose capital is Calcutta.
tossups.answer: Bengal Presidency [accept Presidency of Fort William; accept West Bengal; accept Great Bengal Famine of 1770; prompt on British India before "ruler of"; do not accept or prompt on "Bangladesh"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Bengal Presidency [accept Presidency of Fort William; accept West Bengal; accept Great Bengal Famine of 1770; prompt on British India before "ruler of; do not accept or prompt on "Bangladesh"]

tossups.question: A four-part philosophical poem titled for this concept opens with a "General Analysis" that suggests contemplating the "universal mutability of things" and is by Thomas Love Peacock. Another poem locates this concept's "sovran shrine," where man tastes "Joy's grape," inside the "very Temple of Delight". That poem titled for this concept, which declares "She dwells with Beauty—Beauty that must die," was inspired by a treatise on it by (*) Robert Burton. In a line from "Dover Beach," Matthew Arnold attributes this feeling to the "Sea of Faith" which has a "long, withdrawing roar". John Keats describes how "fits" of this feeling fall "sudden from heaven like a weeping cloud" in an ode which opens "no, go not to Lethe". For 10 points, many Romantics praised what soothing form of sadness?
tossups.answer: melancholy [accept word forms such as melancholic or melancholia; accept The Philosophy of Melancholy or The Anatomy of Melancholy or "Ode on Melancholy"]
tossups.answer_formatted: melancholy [accept word forms such as melancholic or melancholia; accept The Philosophy of Melancholy or The Anatomy of Melancholy or Ode on Melancholy]

tossups.question: This scientist names the problem of finding a configuration of N point charges constrained to the surface of a sphere that minimizes the electrostatic potential. An effect named for him is used in laser diagnostic systems to measure the temperature and electron density of plasmas. A differential cross-section proportional to "one plus cosine squared theta" appears in this scientist's namesake elastic scattering of light by a charged particle, as contrasted with the inelastic (*) Compton scattering. In 1912, this scientist separated neon-20 and neon-22 with electromagnetic fields, thus inventing mass spectrometry. In 1897, he showed that cathode rays are composed of small charged particles. For 10 points, what physicist discovered the electron and proposed the plum pudding model of the atom?
tossups.answer: J. J. Thomson [accept Thomson problem or Thomson scattering; do not accept or prompt on "William Thomson"]
tossups.answer_formatted: J. J. Thomson [accept Thomson problem or Thomson scattering; do not accept or prompt on "William Thomson"]

tossups.question: This novel's narrator remarks on the "sad gray, brown, or black" clothes of people in the marketplace in a chapter describing a public holiday. A mansion in this novel is compared to "Aladdin's palace" and contains a suit of gleaming armor which a girl points out to her mother. This novel concludes by describing a marking "on a field, sable" found on a shared grave in the yard of King's Chapel; the same place is the setting of its first chapter, which describes a (*) rose-bush which grows outside a prison door. Three different scenes in this novel are set at a scaffold, such as one in which a preacher dies after giving a sermon on Election Day due to guilt over his affair with Roger Chillingworth's wife. For 10 points, name this novel about the adultery of Hester Prynne, written by Nathaniel Hawthorne.
tossups.answer: The Scarlet Letter

tossups.question: In one painting, a child-like Envy wears a mask of this person while riding the back of the old hag Avarice next to a scythe-wielding skeleton. A photograph of this person is superimposed on an x-ray in a John Heartfield work, in which gold coins form this person's esophagus. In a painting of a fiery landscape, this person holds a piece of paper to the forehead as his legs are climbed by skeletons. This man commissioned classical sculptures of a (*) decathlete and a victress from Arno Breker. A George Grosz ("gross") painting shows this man "in hell". Artists protested the inclusion of paintings by Franz Marc in an event sponsored by this leader which attacked expressionism and abstraction for undermining culture. For 10 points, what failed painter sponsored the Degenerate Art exhibition as leader of Nazi Germany?
tossups.answer: Adolf Hitler [accept Hitler in Hell] (The first clue is from Otto Dix's Seven Deadly Sins.)
tossups.metadata: The first clue is from Otto Dix's Seven Deadly Sins.

tossups.question: One of these creatures demonstrates his power by reducing a banyan tree to ashes before bribing the sage Kashyapa to let him kill Parikshit; that figure is a king of these creatures named Takshaka. A god reclines on one of these creatures in a motif representing the infinity of the universe called anantashayana. One of these creatures flees to the Yamuna River, since a curse placed by Saubhari prevents his foe from going there, and dwells near a lone Kadamba tree. That one of these creatures named (*) Kaliya ("KAH-lee-yuh") harasses Brindavan until he's banished after Krishna dances on his heads. Vishnu is often depicted resting on the king of these creatures, Shesha. One of these creatures named Vasuki ("VAH-soo-kee") is wrapped around Mount Mandara and used to churn the ocean. For 10 points, name these animals that make up the naga race.
tossups.answer: snakes [or serpents; before mentioned, accept nagas]

tossups.question: Vowels in the writing of these people are predicted using the principle of "synharmony". Many sites built by these people were sketched by Tatiana Proskouriakoff ("pros-koo-REE-ah-koff"), who worked to interpret their writing using the De Landa manuscript with fellow Russian scholar Yuri Knozorov. Inscriptions on their stelae are paired with inscriptions on circular altars, as seen at their site of Izapa. These people wrote royal titles, such as (*) ajaw ("uh-JAO"), using "emblem glyphs". They used a base-20 counting system and divided history into roughly 20-year-long periods called k'atun ("kah-TOON"). These people's ceremonial "long count" system dates the close of the fifth cycle of creation to the 21st century. For 10 points, name these Mesoamerican people whose calendar supposedly predicted the end of the world in 2012.
tossups.answer: Maya [or Mayans; accept K'iche Maya or Yucatec Maya; prompt on Yucatan people]
tossups.answer_formatted: Maya [or Mayans; accept K'iche Maya or Yucatec Maya; prompt on Yucatan people]

tossups.question: In SAXS, one measure of this property can be computed by measuring the slope of a plot of the log of the scattering intensity vs the square of the scattering vector q; that graph is a Guinier plot. This property is computed by plugging a measured translational diffusion coefficient into the Stokes-Einstein equation in a common application of dynamic light scattering. This property is positively correlated with elution time in a technique that uses a column packed with (*) porous beads to separate analytes, called gel permeation chromatography. The "excluded" value of this property gives rise to the second virial coefficient, or, alternately, the "b" term in an equation of state called the van der Waals equation. For 10 points, what property is about 0.62 cubic angstroms for a hydrogen atom?
tossups.answer: molecular size [accept molecular radius, or radius of gyration, or hydrodynamic radius, or root-mean-square radius; accept molecular volume or excluded volume; prompt on molecular shape; do not accept or prompt on "molecular weight" or "molecular mass"] (The "0.62" figure was calculated by assuming that the hydrogen atom is a sphere whose radius is the Bohr radius.)
tossups.answer_formatted: molecular size [accept molecular radius, or radius of gyration, or hydrodynamic radius, or root-mean-square radius; accept molecular volume or excluded volume; prompt on molecular shape; do not accept or prompt on "molecular weight" or "molecular mass"]
tossups.metadata: The "0.62" figure was calculated by assuming that the hydrogen atom is a sphere whose radius is the Bohr radius.

bonuses.leadin: In criticizing the "laziness and cowardice" of men before recent years, this essay proposes the Latin motto Sapere aude!, or "Have the courage to know!" For 10 points each:
answers: "What is Enlightenment?" [or "Answering the Question: What is Enlightenment?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?"]
public AND private [or öffentliche AND privat]
parts: Name this essay which provides an answer to its title question by defining a certain movement as man's emergence from "self-incurred immaturity".
This philosopher from Königsberg wrote "What is Enlightenment," as well as the Critique of Pure Reason.

"What is Enlightenment" distinguishes between uses of reason denoted by these two terms, which respectively refer to use of reason as a scholar before the "world of readers" and in one's own vocation.
answers_formatted: "What is Enlightenment?" [or Answering the Question: What is Enlightenment? or Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?]
acceptable: Answering the Question: What is Enlightenment?
Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about meditations upon death as "lying down":
parts: This meditation on death by William Cullen Bryant declares that "thou shalt lie down / With patriarchs of the infant world".
This poet's "Stanzas Written in Dejection, Near Naples" states "I could lie down, like a tired child...till death like sleep might steal on me". This author eulogized a fellow poet in "Adonais".

A passage of this book remarks that "since our longest sun sets at right declensions," it therefore "cannot be long before we lie down in darkness". This book describes man as a "Noble Animal, splendid in ashes, and pompous in the grave" and was paired with the author’s The Garden of Cyrus.

bonuses.leadin: This statement can be derived by rewriting an integral of the form "e to the negative x plus N times ln x" using Laplace's method of steepest descent, sometimes called the "saddle-point approximation". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this statement used in the derivation of the Sackur-Tetrode equation due to the indistinguishability of gas particles.
Stirling's formula approximates this function. For N distinct particles, the number of permutations is this function of N.
An N factorial term also appears when computing this quantity for multi-particle systems. This quantity is the normalization constant for the Boltzmann distribution.

bonuses.leadin: This text's extended metaphor includes "a blessed olive tree, neither of the east nor of the west". For 10 points each:
answers: Light Verse [or Verse of Light; or Ayah an-Nur; or Ayat an-Nur; accept Quran 24:35]
al-Ghazali [or Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad aṭ-Ṭūsiyy al-Ġaz(z)ālīy; accept Algazelus]
parts: Name this famously esoteric verse of the Qur'an that compares God to an object in a niche. A phrase from this verse is often used to describe God's infinite beauty and guidance.

This Islamic scholar's commentary The Niche of Lights considers three types of light and says that the only true light is God, who is pure light. He promoted occasionalism in a treatise attacking Aristotelian philosophy.
The Light Verse is particularly popular in this mystical Islamic tradition, which holds that all things were created from light.
answers_formatted: Light Verse [or Verse of Light; or Ayah an-Nur; or Ayat an-Nur; accept Quran 24:35]
al-Ghazali [or Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad aṭ-Ṭūsiyy al-Ġaz]
acceptable: Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad aṭ-Ṭūsiyy al-Ġaz

bonuses.leadin: The first ruler of this empire gained the epithet "merciless" for his treatment of the Fulbe ("FULL-bae") tribe. For 10 points each:
answers: (Joannes) Leo Africanus [or Hasan Ibn Muhammad al-Wazzan]
Askia Muhammad I [or Askia the Great; or Muhammad Ture]
parts: Name this empire which displaced the Mali empire in the 15th century under such leaders as Sonni Ali Ber. It had its capital at Gao (rhymes with "cow").

Much of what we know today about the Songhai's conquest of Hausaland comes from this Berber historian, who was captured by Christian pirates in 1518. John Pory translated this historian's Geographical History of Africa into English.
The Songhai empire reached its greatest extent under this leader. He established qadis, or judges, in every Songhai city, and is buried beneath a mud brick pyramid in Gao.
answers_formatted: Askia Muhammad I [or Askia the Great; or Muhammad Ture]

bonuses.leadin: Late in life, this composer wrote a setting of the Stabat Mater that includes a "Cuius animam" for tenor soloist. For 10 points each:
answers: William Tell [accept Guillaume Tell; or Guglielmo Tell]
parts: Name this composer who unusually included twelve singers, two pianos, and a harmonium in his late Petite messe solennelle ("peh-TEET mess soh-leh-NELL").
Rossini only published a few pieces in the years after this opera, whose overture calls for flute and English horn in its Ranz des vaches and ends with a "March of the Swiss Soldiers".

In the last 11 years of his life, Rossini compiled 150 pieces into his Péchés de vieillesse ("peh-SHEH de vee-ay-YEZ"), some of which were arranged into this composer's Rossiniana. This Italian also wrote Ancient Airs and Dances.

bonuses.leadin: In a play inspired by this text, the Union soldier Smith discusses a future in which slaves are freed with the slave Hero. For 10 points each:
answers: dogs [accept The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time]
parts: Name this Greek text which inspired the play Father Comes Home From the Wars. That play's protagonist takes on the name Ulysses in reference to this text's protagonist.

Amusingly, Father Comes Home From the Wars features one of these animals named "Odd-See". A 2012 Simon Stephens play about Christopher Boone titled for one of these animals won seven Laurence Olivier awards.
Father Comes Home From the Wars is by this playwright, who won the 2002 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for a play about Booth and Lincoln, the latter of whom works as an Abraham Lincoln impersonator.
answers_formatted: dogs [accept The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time]
acceptable: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the world sports community's response to apartheid:
parts: As part of the Gleneagles Agreement, heads-of-states from this organization agreed to discourage sporting events with South Africa. This organization mostly consists of former British colonies.
29 countries boycotted the Olympics of this year because New Zealand's rugby team had toured South Africa. Four years later, the U.S. would boycott the Moscow Olympics.
This New Zealand prime minister controversially allowed the 1981 Springbok tour to occur. This prime minister began large-scale infrastructure spending as part of the "Think Big" strategy.
metadata: The Moscow Olympics took place in 1980.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the breadth-first search algorithm:
answers: sparse matrix [accept word forms such as sparseness]
parts: Breadth-first search is contrasted with this type of search, which explores a branch all the way to the end before backtracking.
Breadth-first search can check if a graph has no odd length cycles, which implies this property. Graphs with this property have perfect matchings, which means that they are 2-colorable.

The Cuthill-McKee algorithm uses breadth-first search to permute a matrix that is both symmetric and has this property into a "band" form. Large matrices with this property can be stored compactly in the triplet representation.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about film adaptations of Henrik Ibsen plays:
answers: Andre Gregory [prompt on My Dinner With Andre]
parts: One of this director's final works was 1990's Ganashatru ("GONE-ah-SHAH-thru"), an adaptation of Ibsen's An Enemy of The People. A brother and sister witness a train passing by a crop field in an iconic scene from this director’s Pather Panchali (“puh-THERE pun-CHAH-lee”),

For a 2013 adaptation of The Master Builder, Jonathan Demme ("deh-ME") cast this French-born actor and theater director in the role of Knut Brovik. In another film, this actor meets with a character played by Wallace Shawn in the Café des Artistes.
This actor starred as Torvald Helmer in a 1973 film adaptation of A Doll's House and starred as Dr. Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs.

bonuses.leadin: Journalist Richard Löwenthal ("REE-kard LEOV-en-tall") originated this term to describe Soviet attempts to expand influence in Central Europe. For 10 points each:
answers: Finlandization [or suomettuminen; or Finnlandisierung; or Finlandizatsiya; do not prompt or accept "Finland"]
West Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany or Bundesrepublic Deutschland; prompt on Germany or Deutschland]
parts: Give this term describing the domination of the politics of a small country by a larger neighbor. It originally referred to relations between the Soviet Union and the country it once fought in the Winter War.
The term "Finlandization" originated in debates in this country in the 1960s during the tenure of its SDP leader Willy Brandt ("VIL-ee bront").
The term was popularized by this hardline anti-Communist German political scientist, who lends his name to a 1950s-era policy of trying to isolate East Germany diplomatically.
answers_formatted: Finlandization [or suomettuminen; or Finnlandisierung; or Finlandizatsiya; do not prompt or accept "Finland"]
West Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany or Bundesrepublic Deutschland; prompt on Germany or Deutschland]

bonuses.leadin: In the essay "From [one of these deities] to [the other one]", Georges Dumézil traced them to a common Indo-European notion of initial and final deities also reflected by Vayu and Agni. For 10 points each:
answers: Janus AND Vesta [accept in either order; accept Janus primus, Vesta extrema; prompt on partial answers; accept "De Janus à Vesta" or "From Janus to Vesta"]
crossroads [prompt on intersections, roads, or clear equivalents of either]
parts: Name these two liminal deities who were invoked first and last in Roman rituals. They were also the protectors of weddings.
The Compitalia festival honored Mania and some lares ("LAIR-eez") of these other liminal places. These places were considered gates to the underworld and sacred to the goddess Trivia.
Since both were liminal gods worshiped at crossroads, Romans identified Odin with this psychopomp and father of the lares who carried messages between gods and humans.
answers_formatted: Janus AND Vesta [accept in either order; accept Janus primus, Vesta extrema; prompt on partial answers; accept De Janus à Vesta or From Janus to Vesta]
crossroads [prompt on intersections, roads, or clear equivalents of either]

bonuses.leadin: This author documented the effects of music on psychological phenomena in the book Musicophilia. For 10 points each:
answers: Parkinson's disease [or idiopathic parkinsonism; or primary parkinsonism; or hypokinetic rigid syndrome; or HRS; or paralysis agitans]
parts: Name this neurologist who wrote about administering L-DOPA ("el-doh-pah") to patients in Awakenings, as well as The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat.
The chapter "Kinetic Melody" from Musicophilia describes using music to cure patients with this neurological disease, which results in loss of motor skills often manifested as shaking.

Another chapter of Musicophilia discusses children with this genetic disorder, who often develop great musical talent. Children with it typically develop speech abilities later than others and often suffer from hyperacusia ("hyper-ah-KYOO-zhuh").
answers_formatted: Parkinson's disease [or idiopathic parkinsonism; or primary parkinsonism; or hypokinetic rigid syndrome; or HRS; or paralysis agitans]

bonuses.leadin: Observations of earthquake waveform doublets in the South Sandwich Islands confirmed the observed "super-rotation" of this layer relative to the mantle. For 10 points each:
answers: inner core [do not accept or prompt on "core" or "outer core"]
parts: Inge Lehmann discovered what layer of the Earth, which consists of a solid iron-nickel alloy?
In this phenomenon, heat flow from the inner core contributes to convection currents in the outer core, causing circulating electric currents which generate the Earth's magnetic field.
The inner core's super-rotation was first predicted in 1995 by this first self-consistent numerical model of the geodynamo, developed by two American scientists.
answers_formatted: inner core [do not accept or prompt on "core" or "outer core"]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about social ascent in novels from the Indian subcontinent:
answers: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
parts: Bimala exits the role of a housewife to take part in the Swadeshi movement in this Bengali author's novel The Home and the World. He also wrote the poetry collection Gitanjali ("ghee-TAHN-juh-lee").

In this Aravind Adiga novel framed as a series of letters to Chinese premier Wen Jiabao ("j'yah-bao"), Balram leaves his village to become a chauffeur before moving to Bangalore to start a taxi business.
This Mohsin Hamid novel tells the reader to move to the city, start a water bottling business, get married, and have a son who moves to America in order to accomplish the title goal.
answers_formatted: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
acceptable: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia

bonuses.leadin: Wally Herbert noted that a report that this man was the first to reach the North Pole was "lacking in essential data". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this African-American explorer who discussed his experiences on seven Arctic voyages in A Negro Explorer at the North Pole.
Henson accompanied this American explorer on his expedition to the North Pole in 1909. He reached Greenland's northernmost point, Cape Morris Jessup, on an earlier expedition.
Due to skepticism over Henson's voyage, the first undisputed expedition to the North Pole was led by this Norwegian explorer, the first to reach the South Pole and traverse the Northwest Passage.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about northeastern France:
answers: Lorraine (The three countries are Luxembourg, Belgium, and Germany.)
parts: This northeast region of France is the only French region to border three other countries. It was once part of a state with Alsace.

The Moselle river, which runs through the Lorraine region, names one of these units that is the most populous in Lorraine. France is itself divided into 96 of these administrative units, four of which are located in Lorraine.

This city, the most populous in the Lorraine region, is located at the confluence of the Moselle and Grand Seille ("grahn say") rivers. It is also home to a Georgia Tech campus, as well as a Shigeru Ban-designed Centre Pompidou.
metadata: The three countries are Luxembourg, Belgium, and Germany.

bonuses.leadin: Bernard Ashmole attributed a sculpture depicting a victorious youth to this artist. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sculptor. This sculptor created a statue that shows a man pointing a stirgil towards his right arm that is found in the Vatican Museums.

Possibly a more famous statue of an athlete is this sculptor's Discobolus, which depicts a man about to throw a discus. Pliny the Elder claims that this artist made an extremely-realistic sculpture of a cow.
The Kleophrades painter depicted this goddess on the opposite side of a vase that depicts two athletes kickboxing. Phidias created a gigantic statue of this goddess for the Parthenon.

bonuses.leadin: This country is home to an author who is the namesake of an award given for promoting free speech in literature, who also wrote the essay "Our Need for Consolation is Impossible" and the novel Burnt Child. For 10 points each:
answers: Sweden [or Kingdom of Sweden; or Konungariket Sverige] (The former author is Stig Dagerman.)
parts: Name this country whose literary Nine Society included Karin Boye ("KAH-rin BOH-yuh"), who wrote the dystopian novel Kallocain.
This playwright of The Ghost Sonata and Miss Julie names a prize awarded since 1989 to the best Swedish works of literature.
This Swedish author of Gösta Berling's Saga was the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature and later the first female member of the Swedish Academy.
metadata: The former author is Stig Dagerman.

bonuses.leadin: Acral erythema is a potential complication of this procedure. For 10 points each:
answers: topoisomerases [accept type I topoisomerases or type II topoisomerases or DNA gyrases]
parts: Name this treatment regimen which uses cytotoxic chemicals called "antineoplastic agents" to kill cells. Much like radiation therapy, this procedure can result in hair loss.

Vinca alkaloid chemotherapy drugs act by binding to this protein. Heterodimers of the alpha and beta forms of this protein are polymerized to form structures found in the axoneme and the mitotic spindle.
Irinotecan and doxorubicin are chemotherapy drugs that block the function of these enzymes. Quinolone antibiotics, like levofloxacin, also work by blocking these enzymes.
answers_formatted: topoisomerases [accept type I topoisomerases or type II topoisomerases or DNA gyrases]
